prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: We request two observations at roughly 180 degree separation in longitude on Pluto. Given the 6.4 day rotation period, we need the second observation 3.2 days after the first, which means different hour angles (or LSTs). If that is not achievable, we can accept the second observation at other times, but it will need to be at or close to a particular orbital longitude of Pluto. In that case, once any initial observations are complete, we can provide the days and times on which further observations are acceptable. It will always be better to do the observations as close as possible in time, however, to limit systematics.

We request two observations at roughly 180 degree separation in longitude on Pluto. Given the 6.4 day rotation period, we need the second observation 3.2 days after the first, which means different hour angles (or LSTs). If that is not achievable, we can accept the second observation at other times, but it will need to be at or close to a particular orbital longitude of Pluto. In that case, once any initial observations are complete, we can provide the days and times on which further observations are acceptable. It will always be better to do the observations as close as possible in time, however, to limit systematics.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our correlator setup is standard continuum for band 6, so has no special requirements.

Pluto is ~100 masec in diameter, and for our science goal we must resolve the planet. We would prefer to have even higher resolution than 31 masec, in order to truly resolve the various terrain types from each other, but current cycle 3 capabilities do not allow that. The 31 masec that can be achieved will yield ~10 independent synthesized beams across the face of Pluto, and ~3 across Charon, which will be sufficient to see the largest of the terrain features.

The goal of the project is to accurately measure the variation of brightness temperature across both Pluto and Charon. The best current models for Pluto indicate that there are several different terrain types, corresponding to different types of ices, or ices with different amounts of other materials (see the discussion in the Scientific Justification). Each of these different terrains will have a different brightness temperature [9,10]. In Figure 2 of the Scientific Justification, we show an example of a view of Pluto, with the best-fit terrains, and their corresponding brightness temperatures. That figure shows that the difference between the separate terrain types is about 10 K. In order to distinguish between these different terrains, we must therefore measure 10 K differences with high precision. But we must also consider the smearing of the synthesized beam, which means we do not measure all of the features with infinite resolution (see Figure 2 in the Scientific Justification). Our modeling indicates that a sensitivity of 0.5 K is sufficient, for an SNR of 10, between the various terrains. Given the observing frequency and configuration, this means a noise value of ~28.4 uJy, using the Control and Performance section of the OT. This sensitivity on Pluto will yield similar sensitivity for Charon, though Charon is slightly brighter (per beam, when both are resolved) than Pluto.
We are requesting two visits, to observe two different viewing geometries of Pluto, separated by 180 degrees of longitude. Each of them has the same sensitivity requirement.

We are requesting two separate observations, separated by ~180 degrees of longitude of Pluto, in order to view nearly all longitudes with reasonable geometry. If we are allowed to specify exact longitudes of Pluto, we prefer near 90 and 270 degrees, as the largest terrain feature is centered at 90 degrees. We are willing to accept more arbitrary angles though, as long as they are separated by ~180 degrees. The rotation period of Pluto is ~6.4 days, so this would mean observations separated by ~3.2 days. If, after the initial observation is done, there is some reason why the second cannot be done in the next window (3.2 days later), for weather, instrumental reasons, etc., then we are happy to provide dates and times on which the viewing geometry would be acceptable (though it's as simple as noting when Pluto is visible every 6.4 days after the missed second visit - i.e., after the initial observation, any second observation can occur at a time which is 3.2 + n*6.4 days later, where n is an integer).

We have requested frequencies higher than the default continuum frequencies in band 6, in order to maximize the achievable resolution. There is only a slight sensitivity penalty, which we are willing to pay to get the resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We will use ALMA in configuration C36-8 at 1.1 mm to obtain the first ever spatially resolved images of Pluto and Charon at thermal wavelengths. ALMA is unique in its ability to produce such images, which will be very powerful tools in understanding both the surface and atmosphere of Pluto, and surface of Charon. Accurate measurements of thermal parameters like emissivity, thermal inertia, and the distribution of surface temperatures will aid in modeling the volatile transport on Pluto, which is key to understanding the evolution of its surface and atmosphere over time. With the flyby of New Horizons in July 2015, this project is extremely timely. Data from NH will be critical in our modeling of the thermal emission, and our data will be important in interpreting some NH observations (temperature, albedo, 4.2-cm brightness temperature, etc.).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
